ELECTION OF PRESIDENT OF REPUBLIC OF SINGAPORE


2.30 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move the motion standing in my name,

    That this Parliament, in accordance with Article 1 of the Constitution of Singapore, elects Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares as President of the Republic of Singapore for a further term of four years to commence immediately after the expiry of his present term of office.

    As President, Dr Sheares has undertaken his duties with a conscientiousness which has characterised his whole working life. Unfortunately, in December 1971, his health suffered a setback whilst under examination in hospital at Houston, Texas. Those of us who knew how gravely ill he was, before and after he had his operation in December 1971, were deeply concerned. However, he overcame the setback. Slowly and steadily, he pulled himself up from the aftermath of such a major operation. Courage and tenacity summed up the spirit in the man. He never treated himself as an invalid and, as a consequence, his doctors were surprised and delighted, within less than a year of the operation, to report that he could resume his normal duties.

    Firmly but surely, he adjusted life to his new condition and settled a format for an active intellectual life. He resumed his regular protocol and social duties. He also resumed his teaching and demonstration classes at Kandang Kerbau Hospital, imparting his considerable

Column: 1082

experience and expertise to young doctors aspiring to be gynaecologists.

    He has carried his office with unassuming dignity, application and self-discipline. He has won the respect of all who came to know him. He takes his official and social duties seriously. He has a keen and lively interest in his work. He reads up the background to all the papers that constitutionally have to go to him, and thus is abreast of what is going on in government.

    In moving his re-election, my colleagues and I have every confidence that he will continue to discharge his duties ably. He has now gained wider experience, and a greater understanding of the ways of men and nations. Every dignitary who has had to call on him has received unfailing courtesy. To everyone of them, he has paid the deepest compliment any Head of State can pay, namely, to take a real interest in the man, learn about him and about the country or causes he represents.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

Column: 1083

He has an interest in all spheres of life, not only in social life but also in religious celebrations organised by the various communities in Singapore. For instance, in the annual celebration of the Prophet Mohamed organised by the Muslim Missionary in Lorong 12, Geylang, to commemorate the birth of Prophet Mohamed, leader of the Muslim faith and the apostle of God, President Sheares has never rejected such an invitation. Instead by attending such meetings he contributed valuable speeches for the Muslim people in the Republic. In brief, President Sheares is not only a Professor in Surgery, and an efficient one at that, but he is also a wise and efficient Statesman who has won the hearts and minds of the people. A leader who possesses these qualities can be a symbol of unity among our multi-racial, religious and cultural communities in our Republic.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the re-election of Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares for a second term.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson)(In Tamil): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wholeheartedly support the motion moved by the Prime Minister to re-elect Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares as President for a further term beginning 2nd January, 1975.

    Our President has until today carried out his duties efficiently, thereby earning our praise and respect. Moreover, he has impressed the foreign leaders and diplomats by his intelligence and simplicity. An example of his qualities can be found in the Commonwealth Heads of Government Conference held in our Republic. You may recall that it was just before that Conference that our President first assumed the responsibilities of the office of Head of State. During that important and trying period, when there were so many leaders of the Commonwealth, our President performed his duties as Head of State and received these dignitaries with accord and earned a good reputation. He has established the fact that he is in every respect fit to be a President.

Column: 1084



    I, therefore, sincerely support the re-election of Dr Sheares, who has gained experience in the duties of a Head of State, and I am sure all hon. Members in this House will join me in support.

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to second the motion moved by the Prime Minister to re-elect Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares as the President of the Republic of Singapore for a further term of four years.

    Sir, the President is the Head of a State. In external and internal affairs he symbolises the dignity and the prestige of a country. At the same time he is the highest and model representative of the people. He has to shoulder onerous and important missions of state. Hence, it is very important to choose someone with profound learning, good character and quality, and eminent reputation as President. Looking for such a person may not be too difficult a problem with big countries, but to a small country with a small population such as ours, it really is not an easy task.

    Since assumption of office of the President of the Republic of Singapore, Dr Sheares has fully demonstrated his fine qualities in this appointment. His efforts over the past few years have won for our country a high reputation and prestige abroad. His contributions are what we all can see and praise, with appreciation. From his performance in the past few years, we have reason to believe that Dr Sheares will be able to continue leading our country to march towards a better future.

    Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad to second the motion re-electing Dr Sheares as President of the Republic of Singapore for a further term. We can also assure him here that we will give him our full support and co-operation.

    Question put, and agreed to. Resolved,

    That this Parliament, in accordance with Article 1 of the Constitution of Singapore, elects Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares as President of the Republic of Singapore for a further term of four years to commence immediately after the expiry of his present term of office.

CONTROL OVER NEW LICENCE HOLDERS AND PROFESSIONAL DRIVERS


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Communications (a) if he will consider the display by new licence holders of `P' plates on the front and back of their vehicles for a period of not less than twelve months from the date of issue of their licences, and the requirement that such licence holders undergo a re-test if they are penalised more than six points under the Points Demerit System during that period; and (b) if he will consider the requirement that professional drivers, who are over the age of 60 years, undergo a medical examination.

    Mr Chai Chong Yii (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Transport Advisory Board, now defunct, did discuss the suggestion that new licence holders should display `P' plates on the front and back of their vehicles for a period of time from the date of issue of their licences. The suggestion was not adopted in February 1970 as the members were not convinced that new qualified drivers were more accident-prone than other drivers and that introduction of `P' plate system would help to reduce the accident rate. Information received from a motorist association in New South Wales, Australia, where such a system was in existence showed that although such schemes may have a beneficial psychological effect on drivers, there was no satisfactory statistical information to indicate that such schemes did have effect in reducing accidents. The Registrar of Vehicles has sought for more up-to-date information from the relevant authorities in Australia, and this information is being awaited. If the `P' plate system has been found to reduce accidents involving new licence holders, my Ministry will consider its adoption with favour.

    In the meantime, we shall implement the Points Demerit System and Traffic Ticketing System. We shall find out how effective these two new systems will be in reducing traffic accidents. It is relevant to point out that in the initial

Column: 1088

phase of implementation of the Points Demerit System, only violations of the more serious traffic offences qualifying for four points or more will be recorded. The intention is to concentrate on identifying and weeding out the dangerous and reckless drivers.

    Meanwhile, the Traffic Police and the Registry of Vehicles will review the accident statistics to determine whether there is a correlation between the rates of accidents and the number of years of driving experiences.

    As to medical examination for professional drivers who are over the age of 60 years, this requirement is already in practice under Rule 6 (2) of the Road Traffic (Public Service Vehicles) (Vocational Licences and Conduct of Drivers, Conductors and Passengers) Rules, 1974, whereby no vocational licence for a professional driver shall be granted to a person who is 60 years old or more unless the Registrar of Vehicles is satisfied that such a person is medically fit to be licensed.

ENLISTMENT (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.55 p.m.

    The Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Special Constabulary comprises volunteers and part-time national servicemen. Its members are paid nominal allowances for their services during duty hours. Their employers are under no obligation to pay them the difference between their civilian pay and the allowances paid by the Police for their services. To assist the members of the Special Constabulary the Police Force has, as far as possible, arranged their duty hours such that they suffer minimal disruption in their civilian occupations or suffer loss of personal emoluments. However, in view of a severe manpower shortage, the Police Force intends to utilise the Special Constabulary more intensively. This may result in loss of pay to members of the Special Constabulary unless the Government is in a position to compensate the losses through make-up pay, as is being done in the case of national service reservists.

    Just like the Special Constabulary, the People's Defence Force is also composed of national servicemen and volunteers. Recently the Force was reorganised to enable it to undertake additional operational duties. Members of the People's Defence Force are only paid allowances during their training periods. Unless they are national service reservists, their employers are under no obligation

Column: 1092

to pay them any make-up pay. As a result they too would lose in terms of pay if they are not compensated.

    It is intended to remedy the situation through this Amendment Bill. The Bill seeks to repeal and re-enact section 24 of the Enlistment Act (i.e, the present provision providing for make-up pay). Apart from making provision for makeup pay for the categories who are already eligible, the Bill requires employers to pay make-up salary to both the volunteers and national servicemen (i.e, those who are performing part-time service) in the People's Defence Force and the Special Constabulary when they are called up for training or reserve service and to volunteers in these Forces when they are mobilized. Employers may deduct the amount paid from their payroll tax. Those employers who are not liable to pay payroll tax, and those whose payroll tax is insufficient for such deductions, may claim reimbursement from Government. Self-employed members of the People's Defence Force and the Special Constabulary can claim reimbursement also from Government.

    The Bill also provides that employers of volunteers in the People's Defence Force and the Special Constabulary are to continue to make Central Provident Fund contributions to the extent that they would be liable had the volunteers not been mobilized for full-time service or called up for training.

    The Bill repeals section 13 of the Vigilante Corps Act and with this repeal, volunteers in the Vigilante Corps will not be liable for full-time mobilization. There are two main reasons for repealing section 13. First, it is unfair to impose the liability of mobilization on volunteers in the Vigilante Corps. Secondly, it is not intended to mobilize the volunteers anyway, as there are large numbers of national servicemen doing part-time service in the Vigilante Corps.

    The other important points in the Bill relate to reinstatement in employment, prohibition against dismissal and leave of absence when performing service. The provisions in respect of these matters are found in sections 21, 22 and

Column: 1093

23 of the Act. In the Bill these three sections have been amended so as to extend them to the volunteers in the People's Defence Force and the Special Constabulary.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I am happy to clarify that. There are two types of daily-rated workers. One is a person who, although he may be daily-rated, is on regular employment in a firm. To that extent, he is covered by the provisions of this Bill. The other type are often casual workers going from one place to another, particularly in the construction industry. It is very difficult to cover them here because they change employers so often that you cannot pin them to any particular employer. In effect, such people would come under the category of "own account" workers, of which there are quite a substantial number in the reservists.

SINGAPORE COUNCIL OF SOCIAL SERVICE (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.02 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Column: 1094



    The Singapore Council of Social Service (Amendment) Bill was introduced in Parliament on 23rd October, 1974. This Bill, now before the House, seeks to make amendments to the Singapore Council of Social Service Act, 1968, in the light of the experience gained by the Council in administering the Act over the years.

    The Council was formally established with the following objectives:

    (a) to co-ordinate the voluntary welfare activities in Singapore not only between its member organisations, but also with other organisations;

    (b) to maintain and improve standards of voluntary social work and to encourage voluntary welfare efforts in fields not fully covered by Government;

    (c) to assist member organisations in their efforts to promote welfare activities in Singapore;

    (d) to initiate, assist and organise forms of relief and schemes of social service;

    (e) to disseminate information to members of the public and interest them in social welfare matters and to encourage their participation in these matters; and

    (f) to make recommendations to Government regarding legislation in the field of social welfare.

    In the course of administering the Act to achieve these objectives, the Council has encountered some problems and this is why my Ministry has proposed the amendments in this Bill. I shall now elaborate on these problems.

    Past experience shows that many purely religious and non-welfare related organisations have sought affiliation with the Council.

    However, the Council's main interest and focus is on welfare and social service. It is therefore proposed that the Singapore Council of Social Service Act be amended to limit purely religious and non-welfare related organisations from seeking affiliation to the Council. Such organisations which seek to carry

Column: 1095

out welfare and social service activities and wish to affiliate with the Council must establish a separate structure for social and welfare activities and could then seek affiliation in their own right.

    Under current legislation, any person, firm, corporation or organisation which subscribes not less than $25 per year may be an associate of the Council. Likewise, any organisation affiliated to the Council must subscribe not less than $10 to the Council. The Council has, among its associates and member organisations, a wide-ranging group of bodies, including many well-known firms and corporations. The present subscription of $25 per annum for associates can be considered negligible. My Ministry therefore proposes an amendment to allow the Council to charge any subscription it thinks fit for associates as well as for member organisations.

    There are many people who are interested in welfare work but who, for some personal reason, do not wish to be attached to any particular welfare organisation. Such people should be encouraged, nevertheless, to contribute towards the work of the Council. It is proposed that the Council be empowered to appoint such people as honorary members, in addition to the patrons-in-chief and patrons whom the Council is already authorised to appoint. In this way, more people could contribute actively towards the work of the Council. Such honorary members will, however, be restricted from holding office and voting in the Board of Management of the Council.

    As regards the Board of Management, whose members are elected by the Council from among its member organisations and associates or are ex-officio members, there is a provision in the Amendment Bill which stipulates that only those who are confirmed as still being representatives of member organisations can be re-elected to office in the Board. In this way, the Council hopes to ensure that only those who are still actively involved in the work of its various members are allowed to be

Column: 1096

elected or to hold office on the Board of Management of the Council.

    In addition to the Annual General Meeting, the Council also holds two general meetings each year. This is specified in the Singapore Council of Social Service Act.     The following Bills were assented to by the President of the Republic of Singapore on the date stated:

2nd December, 1974

    (i) Road Traffic (Amendment) Bill;

    (ii) Naval and Air Bases (Repeal) Bill;

    (iii) Enlistment (Amendment) Bill;

    (iv) Singapore Council of Social Service (Amendment) Bill;

    (v) State Lands Encroachments (Amendment) Bill;

    (vi) Abortion Bill;

    (vii) Voluntary Sterilization Bill;

    (viii) Police Force (Amendment) Bill;

    ( ix) Cancellation of Planning Permission Bill;

    (x) Foreshores (Amendment) Bill;

    (xi) Jurong Town Corporation (Amendment) Bill; and

    (xii) National Police Cadet Corps Bill.
